header.title: Rape charity target of ‘racist’ abuse due to ‘misleading’ Tommy Robinson post
header.postText: A charity supporting rape victims say they have received ‘abusive phone calls’ after Tommy Robinson shared a picture of their leaflet.', 'The Rape Crisis pamphlet addressed black, Asian and minority ethnic women who had experienced sexual violence and urged them to seek support.', 'It then offered a phone number, telling victims that Punjabi, Hindi and English support workers are available.', 'Far-right campaigner Robinson shared the leaflet on his Facebook page on February 14, writing: ‘I guess it’s ok to rape white women then?’', 'Rape Crisis Wycombe, Chiltern and South Bucks said that since then they have had a ‘significant volume of abusive phone calls, messages and emails’, many of which were of a ‘overtly racist nature’.', 'Workers have reported the incident to police and slammed the callers for ‘disrupting much-needed service provision for victims and survivors of sexual violence’.', '‘Rape Crisis (Wycombe, Chiltern and South Bucks) recognises that some groups of women who have survived sexual violence and abuse can face additional barriers to accessing services, including related to language and to the fear and/or past or current experience of racism and racial discrimination,’ the charity said in a statement.', '‘As part of its commitment to accessibility and inclusion, it therefore offers a specialist service for black, Asian and minority ethnic women aimed at overcoming some of these barriers.’', 'The charity blamed Robinson’s ‘misleading caption’ on social media for the torrent of abusive messages and calls.', 'It added: ‘Rape Crisis England & Wales supports Rape Crisis (Wycombe, Chiltern and South Bucks) and all its member Rape Crisis Centres in the provision of fully inclusive, accessible services, including specialist work with specific groups of under-served, minoritised or marginalised victims and survivors.’', 'Some of Robinson’s one million followers had commented on the picture of the leaflet calling it ‘horrendous’, ‘discriminative’ and ‘out of order’.', 'One wrote: ‘Think we all need to phone the numbers advertised & put in a racist complaint.’', '‘Is it our turn to play the racist card now,’ another added.', 'But some Facebook commentators did defend the charity, writing: ‘Good grief, It’s an additional phone line.', '‘Tommy doesn’t seem to understand, or want to understand, that there is a cultural stigma that brings shame on both the victims and their families so they are less likely to report it.', '‘The helpline is English, Hindi and Punjabi and operated by a worker who understands those particularly difficulties.’', 'Another said: ‘It’s a specialist line with experienced and trained translators. Hardly rocket science.’', 'Robinson told Metro.co.uk he had ‘asked a valid question’ as ‘the poster excluded white people which is becoming more frequent’.', '‘I asked a question – it was not a call to action and I did not ask anyone to contact the organisation,’ he said.', '‘If anyone has harassed the organisation then that is 100% wrong.’

Jay Hopkinson Changing his name is hiding it. A far-right activist called Stephen Yaxley-Lennon wouldn't be taken seriously, so he picked a name that made him sound working class. It doesn't matter that we know his birth name, he continues to use his chosen name, and hide his former identity behind his new one. Unless you're saying he greets new people with "I'm Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, but everyone calls me Tommy Robinson.", which would be ridiculous. For someone who claims they have read this story "20 times", you seem to have missed this paragraph; "Rape Crisis Wycombe, Chiltern and South Bucks said that since then they have had a ‘significant volume of abusive phone calls, messages and emails’, many of which were of a ‘overtly racist nature’." This would be the unnamed people attacking the charity, although you probably call it "fair criticism". This particular poster was created to highlight a specialist helpline for women who might not use English as a first language, or who may not feel comfortable talking to a white person about suffering rape, thanks to all the anti-immigrant rhetoric going around at the moment. Finally, you can call me a dickhead all you want. I've been called worse, and for so long that insults no longer bother me. I wonder if your parents are disappointed in you. They should be. To the point they regret your existence.
